Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Story: I was scrubbing the kitchen floor, glancing at the clock every few minutes. My wife was bustling around, her voice echoing from the living room, “Can you vacuum next? My cousins will be here in two hours!” I nodded, feeling the pressure mount. The house had to be spotless—she was counting on me to help make a good impression. My phone buzzed. It was a customer, texting about a package I was supposed to deliver this morning. “Where is my order? I need it urgently.” At the same time, a notification popped up: the package was delayed at the depot, and I’d have to call the customer to explain. I could hear my wife sighing, the vacuum still untouched. My mind raced—should I step outside to make the call, risking her frustration, or ignore the customer for now and help at home, risking a complaint at work? Both sides expected me to be present, responsible, and calm. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, torn between the demands of my job and my family, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
